newsitem.title: UK: British bosses fear economy is overheating-survey.
newsitem.headline: British bosses fear economy is overheating-survey.

text.p: Three quarters of Britain's managers fear the UK economy is dangerously close to overheating, the Institute of Management(IM) said on Monday.
Its survey found 82 percent of managers say unless the spending boom is curbed inflation will exceed the government's 2.5 percent target this year.

Some 64 percent of managers say they would prefer further increases in interest rates to rising inflation, although 74 percent said they are concerned about the impact on business of future interest rate rises, in particular the effect it could have on sterling.

The pound has gained around 25 percent on a trade weighted basis since last August. However, only just over one third (36 percent) of managers said the pound's level was having an adverse affect on their business, although this is up from 17 percent in March.
"The rising temperature on Britain's high streets is starting to make managers sweat," said Roger Young, director-general at IM.
"Concern is growing that the economy is teetering on the brink and could be in for a hard landing."
The survey was conducted last week and 266 managers replied.
